div.l: AT Trumpynton / nought fer fro Cambrigge
Ther goth a broke / ⁊and ouer that a brigge
Vppon the which broke / ther stante a melle
And this is verray soth / that I yow telle
A Miller͗e was there / duellyng many a yere dayyereday
As eny pecok / he was proude ⁊and gay
Pipen he couthe ⁊and fisshen ⁊and nettes bete
And torne coppes / ⁊and wel wrastle ⁊and shete
Ay bi his belt / he bar a longe panade
And of a swerd / ful trenchaunt was the blade
A ioly popper bar he / on his pouche
Ther was no man for ꝑperil / durste him touche
A sheffeld twetil / bar he in his hose
Round was his face / camused was his nose
As piled as an ape / was his sculle
He was a markat beter / at the fulle
Ther was no wight / that durst hand on him legge
But if he swore anoon / he sholde a begge There is an erasure above the "e" in "begge," consistent with a possible original reading "bygge" or "bigge."
A theff he was for soth of corn ⁊and mele
And that a sleigh / ⁊and vsaunt for stele
His name was hoten deynous symkyn
A wiff he hadde comen of noble kyn
¶ The ꝑperson of the town̄ / hir fader was
With hir he yaff / ful may a panne of bras
For that symkyn / shulde in his blood allye
She was I fostered / in a Nonnerye
For symkyn wolde no wiff / as he saide
But she were wel I norsshed / ⁊and a maide
To sauen his estate / of yomanrye
And she was proude ⁊and perte / as is a pye
A ful faire sight was it / vppon hem two
On halidayes to forn hir / wolde he go
With his tipet wonden / al aboute his hede
And she cam after / in a gyte of rede
And Symkyn hadde hosen / of the same
Ther durst no wight / clepen hir but dame
